title: Distances Between Partial Preference Orderings
abstract: This paper proposes to establish the distance between partial preference orderings based on two very different approaches. The first approach corresponds to the brute force method based on combinatorics. It generates all possible complete preference orderings compatible with the partial preference orderings and calculates the Frobenius distance between all fully compatible preference orderings. Unfortunately, this first method is not very efficient in solving high-dimensional problems because of its big combinatorial complexity. That is why we propose to circumvent this problem by using a second approach based on belief functions, which can adequately model the missing information of partial preference orderings. This second approach to the calculation of distance does not suffer from combinatorial complexity limitation. We show through simple examples how these two theoretical methods work.

sections.title: I. INTRODUCTION
sections.content:
In operational research and multi-criteria decision-making (MCDM) problems, we are often faced with dealing with information expressed as preference orderings (PO), especially if human experts provide their opinions about the problem under concern only as preferences between several objects (or alternatives) and express qualitatively or quantitatively. The PO given by the source of information are not always total preference orderings (TPOs) (i.e., full or complete PO) but only defined partially, and we have to deal efficiently with this type of partial preference orderings (PPOs) to infer some important decision to make.
There exist several works on metrics and near metrics (i.e., similarity measures) between ranked data, and ranking aggregation is problematic, see [1]–[4]. Most of these works are based on Spearman's footrule [5] and Kendall's correlation coefficient [6], [7], and they fail to take into account element relevance and positional information [8]. An appealing axiomatic approach to define the distance between TPO had been proposed in the sixties by Kemeny [7], [9] and is often used in applications. Recently, we have proved in [10] that Kemeny's distance is not the unique distance satisfying Kemeny's axioms, and the Frobenius distance can be used instead for measuring the distance between two TPOs. This paper extends our previous work and shows how it is possible to exploit this Frobenius distance to measure the distance between two PPOs without involving combinatorics.
Before presenting in detail the theoretical solutions we propose, we recall briefly the basics about the comparison of objects in Section II, Frobenius distance between total preference orderings in Section III, and belief functions in Section IV. Then, we present the brute force method (BFM) based on combinatorics in Section V with examples for calculating the distance between PPOs. To circumvent the complexity limitations of BFM in Section VI, we propose two methods of distance calculation based on belief functions, and we compare them with BFM in some examples. Section VII concludes this paper with some perspectives on MCDM and information fusion applications.

sections.title: II. COMPARISON OF TWO OBJECTS
sections.content:
Let's consider two objects¹ A and B, with their score denoted by c(A) and c(B) based on some chosen criteria of evaluation c(.). The score value can be quantitative (i.e., a number) or qualitative² (i.e. a label). Based on the score values and adopting the convention "higher score is better", in the classical preference model, we assume that we can always compare two objects and express the preference ordering between these two objects as follows:
• A preferred to B for sure is denoted A > B where A > B ⇔ c(A) > c(B), which is equivalent to B 人 A where B < A ⇔ c(B) < c(А).
• B preferred to A for sure is denoted B > A where B > A ⇔ c(B) > c(A), which is equivalent to A 人 B where A < B ⇔ c(A) < c(B).

sections.title: III. DISTANCE BETWEEN TWO TΤΡΟΣ
sections.content:
We consider here a set X of n ≥ 2 objects that are all ranked by two sources of information, and we denote Pref₁ and Pref2 each total³ preference ordering (TPOs) of objects given by the sources. For instance, if we consider a set of three objects X = {x1 = A, x2 = B, x3 = C'}, then we may have the preference Pref₁ given by the source 1, and the preference Pref2 by the source 2, with the following TPOs Pref₁ ≡ A > B > C and Pref2 ≡ B > C > A.
In this section, we explain how to measure the distance between two TPOs Pref₁ and Pref₁ in general case. For this, we use the Frobenius distance between two total orderings (i.e. preference orderings including eventual ties) proposed in [10] as a serious alternative to classical Kemeny's distance [9], and to Spearman's footrule distance (i.e. F-distance) [5]. The advantage of Frobenius distance is that it is a true metric, and it is quite simple to calculate. Contrary to the F-distance, the Frobenius distance satisfies the essential invariance under the indexing principle [10]. Moreover, the Frobenius distance also satisfies all of Kemeny's axioms. Hence, the well-known Kemeny's distance is not unique, and we have shown why Frobenius's distance is appealing with respect to Kemeny's distance through simple examples in [10].

sections.title: A. Definition
sections.content:
Frobenius distance between two TPOs (i.e. orderings) of N objects is done by calculating at first the N × N pairwise Preference-Score Matrix (PSM) based on the ordering given by each expert. By convention, the row index i of the PSM corresponds to the index of elements xi on the left side of preference ordering xi ➤ xj, and the column index j of the PSM corresponds to the index of the element x; on the right side of preference ordering Xi ➤ Xj. Hence we denote a pairwise Preference-Score Matrix M(X) = [M(i, j)] where its components M(i, j) for i, j = 1, 2, . . ., N are defined as
$M(i, j) = \begin{cases} 1, & \text{if } X_i \succ X_j, \\ -1, & \text{if } X_i \prec X_j, \\ 0, & \text{if } X_i = X_j. \end{cases}$       (1)
Note that all components M(i, i) (i = 1, 2, ..., N) of the main diagonal of the matrix M are always equal to zero. Also, PSM is always an anti-symmetrical matrix by construction because the preference xi ➤ xj is equivalent to the preference XjXi. Hence if xi > xj is true which means M(i,j) = 1 then necessarily xj > xi is false which means that xj < xi is true and thus M(j, i) = −1, and the other way around. Consequently, M(X)T = −M(X), and Tr(M(X)) = 0.
The distance between two TPOs Pref1 and Pref2 is defined by the Frobenius distance as follows [10]:
$d_F(M_1, M_2) = ||M_1 - M_2||_F,$       (2)
where $||M||_F$ is the Frobenius norm of a square matrix M = [M(i, j), i, j = 1,..., N] defined by [11], [12]
$||M||_F = \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n |M(i, j)|^2} = \sqrt{Tr(M^T M)},$       (3)
and where $M^T$ is the transpose of the matrix M, and Tr(.) is the trace operator for matrix.
Frobenius distance is usually normalized in [0, 1] interval by dividing the value dF(M1, M2) by the maximal distance value dmax calculated by considering two TPOs in full contradiction (i.e. a preference and its opposite defined by reversing the preference order). For instance, if a preference ordering is Pref = A > B > C > D, its opposite is Pref = A 人 B人C人 D=D> C > B > A.

sections.title: B. Example 1
sections.content:
Consider the set X {x1 = A, x2 = B, x3 = C'} of three objects A, B and C, and the two total preference orderings
$\{\text{Pref}_1 \equiv B \succ A \succ C, \\ \text{Pref}_2 \equiv B \succ C \succ A.$       
Based on (1), we obtain the PSM matrices
$M_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 & 1 \\ -1 & -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad M_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & -1 \\ -1 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & -1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}.$       
Because
$(М1 – M2)T (М1 – M2) = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$      (5)
one has Tr(M1 – М2)Т (М1 – M2) = 8.
Applying (2) with PSMs M₁ and M2 the Frobenius distance between Pref₁ and Pref2 is equal to
$d_F(M_1, M_2) = \sqrt{8} \approx 2.8284.$       
The maximal value dmax of dF(M1, M2) is calculated in considering two TPOs in full contradiction (i.e., a preference and its opposite defined by reversing the preference order). For instance, in considering Pref = A > B > C, and its opposite Pref = A 人 B 人C=C>1 B<C=C > B > A and building PSM by (1) and applying (2). In our example we obtain, dmax = √24 ≈ 4.8990.
Therefore, the normalized Frobenius distance dr between Pref₁ and Pref2 is given by
$\bar{d}_F(M_1, M_2) = \sqrt{8} / \sqrt{24} = 1/\sqrt{3} \approx 0.5774.$
Using the alternative PSM definition (4), we obtain the PSM matrices
$M_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 0.5 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0.5 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0.5 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad M_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 0.5 & 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 0.5 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0.5 \end{bmatrix}$       
Because
(M₁ – М₂) (М – М₂) = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$       (6)
one has Tr(M₁ – М₂)T (M₁ – M₂) = 2.
Applying (2) with PSMs given in (III-B), the Frobenius distance between Pref1 and Pref2 is equal to
$d_F(M_1, M_2) = \sqrt{2} \approx 1.4142.$       
The maximal value dmax of dF(M1, M2) is calculated in considering two TPOs in full contradiction. In our example we have dmax = √6 = √2 - √3.
Therefore, the normalized Frobenius distance between Pref₁ and Pref2 based on alternative PSM definition (4), is given by
$\bar{d}_F(M_1, M_2) = \sqrt{2}/\sqrt{6} = 1/\sqrt{3} \approx 0.5774.$

sections.title: IV. BELIEF FUNCTIONS
sections.content:
The belief functions (BF) were introduced by Shafer [13] for modeling epistemic uncertainty, reasoning about uncertainty, and combining distinct sources of evidence. The answer to the problem under concern is assumed to belong to a known finite discrete frame of discernment (FoD) Θ = {01,...,0} where all elements (i.e., members) of O are exhaustive and exclusive. The set of all subsets of O (including empty set Ø, and ⊕) is the power-set of O denoted by 29. The number of elements (i.e., the cardinality) of the power set is 2||. A (normalized) basic belief assignment (BBA) associated with a given source of evidence is a mapping m®(·) : 2º → [0,1] such that m®(0) = 0 and ∑x∈20 m®(X) = 1. A BBA m®(·) characterizes a source of evidence related to a FoD Θ. For notation shorthand, we can omit the superscript Ѳ in m⊕(·) notation if there is no ambiguity on the FoD we work with. The quantity m(X) is called the mass of belief of X. X ∈ 2º is called a focal element (FE) of m(·) if m(X) > 0. The set of all focal elements of m(·) is denoted by Fe(m) ≡ {X ∈ 2®|m(X) > 0}. The belief and the plausibility of X are respectively defined for any X ∈ 2º by [13].
$Bel(X) = \sum_{Y \in 2^{\Theta}, Y \subseteq X} m(Y),$       (7)
$Pl(X) = \sum_{Y \in 2^{\Theta}, X \cap Y \neq \emptyset} m(Y) = 1 - Bel(\bar{X}),$       (8)
where X ≒ ⊙ \ {X} is the complement of X in Θ.
One has always 0 ≤ Bel(X) ≤ Pl(X) ≤ 1, see [13]. For X = 0, Bel(0) = Pl(0) = 0, and for X = Θ one has Bel(Θ) = ΡΙ(Θ) = 1. Bel(X) and Pl(X) are often interpreted as the lower and upper bounds of unknown probability P(X) of X, that is Bel(X) < P(X) < Pl(X). To quantify the uncertainty (i.e. the imprecision) of P(X) ∈ [Bel(X), Pl(X)], we use u(X) ∈ [0, 1] defined by
$u(X) \equiv Pl(X) – Bel(X).$       (9)
If all focal elements of m(·) are singletons of 2 the BBA m(·) is a Bayesian BBA because ∀X ∈ 2º one has Bel(X) = Pl(X) = P(X) and u(X) = 0. Hence, the belief and plausibility of X coincide with a probability measure P(X) defined on the FoD Θ. The vacuous BBA characterizing a totally ignorant source of evidence is defined by mr(X) = 1 for X = Θ, and m₂(X) = 0 for all X ∈ 2º different of Ө. This very particular BBA is very important to model missing information in the PPOs as it will be shown in Section VI.

sections.title: V. DISTANCE BETWEEN TWO PPOS BY BFM
sections.content: In practice, the calculation of the distance between PPOs is of main importance because TPOs are not always available to calculate directly their proximity by the Frobenius distance presented in Section III. The main question is how to calculate the distance between two POs when at least one is partially known. From the theoretical standpoint, the combinatorial solution based on the brute force method (BFM) seems appealing because it will enumerate all compatible TPOs (i.e., CTPOs) with the given PPOs, and it computes the Frobenius distances between all CTPOs pairs and makes a decision from of all them based on different decisional attitudes. This section presents in detail the BFM.

sections.title: A. The brute force method (BFM)
B. Example 2
sections.content: Consider the objects {A, B, C} and the two PPOs given by Pref₁ = C > A and Pref2 = A > B. Pref₁ and Pref2 are both PPOs because they include only two objects among three. For applying BFM, we must consider all TPOs listed in Table II that are compatible with Pref₁ on one hand and compatible with Pref2 on the other hand. By examining all possible TPOs generated by brute force combinatorics (see Table I), we observe that we have only NTPO = 5 CPTOs with Pref₁ which are listed in Table II, and NCTPO = 5 CTPOs with Pref2 as listed in Table II.

sections.title: VI. SOLUTION BY THE BELIEF FUNCTIONS APPROACH
sections.content:
In practice, the preference ordering of two objects, say X and Y, is not always easy to make, mainly because of the lack of pertinent/useful information to establish the scores or because of the very high complexity of calculating precisely the score values, or the difficulty to establish a personal judgment about the objects. In this situation, a choice between preferences X > Y, X < Y, and indifference X = Y is just impossible to make with certainty. In extreme cases, a preferential choice cannot be made at all because of the lack of evidence to support any preference. This corresponds to the full uncertain preference case denoted for short by X?Y or equivalently denoted by Y?X. The notation X?Y represents the total uncertainty about preferences X > Y, X < Y, and indifference X = Y, which corresponds actually to their disjunction. More precisely, one has
$X?Y = Y?X = (X \succ Y) \cup (X = Y) \cup (X \prec Y).$       (10)

sections.title: A. BBA modeling from preference
sections.content:
To model the uncertainty about preference orderings, we adopt here the belief function formalism [13], and we introduce the simplest preferential frame of discernment Ox,y between two objects X and Y defined by the three exclusive and exhaustive preferences states 01 ≒ (X > Y), 02 ≒ (X = Y), and 03 ≡ (X < Y). Hence, we will work with the FoD
$\Theta_{X,Y} \triangleq \{\theta_1 \triangleq X \succ Y, \, \theta_2 \triangleq X = Y, \, \theta_3 \triangleq X \prec Y\}.$       (11)
The notation Ox,y is necessary because we need to specify precisely the two elements X and Y involved in the analysis of the PPO under concern. We will eventually omit the X, Y index for whenever possible if there is no confusion on the elements X and Y we are working with (by default, we consider the elements or objects X and Y).
To address some problems where PPOs and uncertainty occur, we can consider that the preference orderings are not necessarily true or false (as in the classical preference model), but they can better be modeled by a basic belief function m(.) : 2Өx,x → [0,1] with m(Ø) = 0 and ∑ze2@x,y m(Z) = 1, where 2⊕x,r is the power set (i.e. the set of all the subsets) of Oxy given by
$2^{\Theta_{X,Y}} = \{\emptyset, \, \{\theta_1\}, \, \{\theta_2\}, \, \{\theta_1 \cup \theta_2\}, \, \{\theta_3\}, \, \{\theta_1 \cup \theta_3\}, \, \{\theta_2 \cup \theta_3\}, \, \{\theta_1 \cup \theta_2 \cup \theta_3\}\}.$

sections.title: B. Construction of BBA matrices based on belief masses
sections.content:
Because it is impossible to calculate each component M(i, j) of PSM from (1) without high combinatorics (see BFM of Section V), we propose to circumvent this combinatorial problem by exploiting belief functions. Before calculating the distance between PPOs based on the belief functions, it is necessary to construct a BBA matrix associated with each (partial) preference ordering based on the BBA modeling from preferences presented just before. Two types of methods are analyzed in this work to establish the distance between two PPOs: the direct method based on the BBAs matrices, which requires calculating the Frobenius distance between two (8N × 8N) matrices, and two indirect methods based on distances between BBAs, which require the calculation of the Frobenius distance between two PSM-alike matrices of dimension N × N only. We present briefly these different approaches next.
1) Direct method: For each object Xi (i = 1, . . ., N) we first establish the BBA matrices BBA1 and BBA2 from preferences Pref₁ and Pref2 respectively based on the previous BBA modeling (see subsection VI-A, and the next examples). Because we work with FoD of cardinality three defined by (11), each BBA of the BBA matrix has 23 = 8 components. Hence, BBA1 and BBA2 matrices will be sparse matrices of dimension 8N × 8N. Once the BBA1 and BBA2 are built, we use the "extended PSM" matrices M₁ = BBA₁ and M2 = BBA2. Then, we apply the classical Frobenius distance definition dF(M1, M2) to calculate the distance between the two PPOs Pref1 and Pref2. It is worth mentioning that in order to deal with the mathematical representation of uncertainty by belief functions, we have changed the paradigm, and the “PSM matrices” are no longer N × N matrices anymore (as defined classically) but extended into 8N × 8N BBA matrices whose components correspond to belief mass values defined with respect to different FoD defined in (11).
2) Indirect methods: In order to work with belief functions and with PSM matrices of dimension N × N instead of 8N × 8N, we examine the possibility to redefine each component M(i, j) of PSM-alike matrix from the distance of the BBA mөх, х with respect to the BBA mx₁>x₁. Here mөx₁,x; is the BBA built on Ox₁,x, from the given (partial) preference ordering, and mx₁>x; is the BBA focused on the element 0₁ = X₁ > Xj of the FoD Ox₁,x; (i.e. mx₁>X₁ (01) = 1). More precisely, we will define the Preference-Score alike Matrix M(X) = [M(i, j)] from its components M(i, j) for i, j = 1, 2, ...,n defined as
$M(i, j) = d(m_{\Theta_{x_i, x_j}}, m_{x_i \succ x_j}).$       (12)
where d(,) is a distance measure between two BBAs. In this paper, we use Jousselme distance dj and the belief-interval- based distance dBi to get results because they are the two main well-known normalized distances often used in the BF framework. Due to space limit restriction, we do not give definitions of these distances, which are given in [17], [18] for dj, and in [19], [20] for dBI. Once the PSMs-alike are obtained by (12), we use the classical Frobenius distance definition (2) to calculate the distance between the two PPOs.

sections.title: C. Example 1 revisited
sections.content:
We present the results of the direct and indirect methods using the belief function, for the example, 1 of Section III involving 3 objects {X1 A, X2 B,X3 C'} and the two TPOs Pref₁ = B > A > C and Pref2 = B > C > A. The matrix BBA₁ of (13) requires the BBAs mi,j (i, j = 1,2,3) with the following masses of focal elements: m1,2(03 = (X1 < X2) = 1, m1,3(01 = (X1 > X3)) = 1, m2,1(01 = (X2 > X1) = 1, m2,3(01 = (X2 > X3)) = 1, m3,1(03 = (X3 < X1)) = 1, and m3,2(03 = (X3 < X2)) = 1. For the diagonal BBAs, m1,1(02 = (X1 = X₁)) = 1, m2,2(02 = (X2 = X2)) = 1, and m3,3(02 = (X3 = X3)) = 1. Therefore, we have10
$\\text{BBA}_1 \begin{array}{c|ccc} & m_{1,1} & m_{1,2} & m_{1,3} \\ & m_{2,1} & m_{2,2} & m_{2,3} \\ & m_{3,1} & m_{3,2} & m_{3,3} \end{array}$       (13)
with mass functions defined by the vectors11
m1,1 = [00100000], m1,2 = [00001000], m1,3 = [01000000]
= [01000000], m2,2 = [00100000], m2,3 = [01000000]
m3,1 = [00001000], m3,2 = [00001000], m3,3 = [00100000]
Similarly, we will have
$\text{BBA}_2 \begin{array}{c|ccc} & m_{1,1} & m_{1,2} & m_{1,3} \\ & m_{2,1} & m_{2,2} & m_{2,3} \\ & m_{3,1} & m_{3,2} & m_{3,3} \end{array}$       (14)
with mass functions defined by the vectors
m1,1 = [00100000], m1,2 = [00001000], m1,3 = [00001000]
= [01000000], m2,2 = [00100000], m2,3 = [01000000]
m3,1 = [01000000], m3,2 = [00001000], m3,3 = [00100000]
With the direct method, we take M₁ = BBA₁ and M2 = BBA2, and therefore the distance between Pref₁ ≡ B > A > C and Pref2 = B > C > A is dF(M1, M2) = 2. It can be easily verified12 that the maximal Frobenius distance is dF(M1, M2) ≈ 3.4641. Therefore, the normalized distance between Pref1 and Pref2 is dF(M1,M2) = 2/3.4641 = 0.5774. This result coincides with the normalized Frobenius distance given by the classical method described in the subsection III-B.
With the indirect methods, it turns out that we obtain the same PSM-alike matrices M₁ and M2 if we use Jousselme distance [17], or the belief-interval based distance [19], and we get
$M_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad M_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

sections.title: D. Example 2 revisited
sections.content:
Consider 3 objects {X₁ ≡ A, X2 ≡ B, X3 ≡ C'} and the two PPOs Pref₁ = C > A, and Pref2 = A > B. From the knowledge of Pref1, the BBA matrix BBA1 of the form (13) has the following components
m1,1 = [00100000], m1,2 = [00000001], m1,3 = [00001000]
= [00000001], m2,2 = [00100000], m2,3 = [00000001]
m3,1 = [01000000], m3,2 = [00000001], m3,3 = [00100000]
The BBAs m1,2, m2,1, M2,3, and m3,2 correspond to the vacuous belief masses because we do not have information about the preference between B and A and between B and C based on the PPO Pref₁ = C > A.
Similarly, from the knowledge of Pref2, the BBA matrix BBA2 of the form (14) has the following components
m1,1 = [00100000], m1,2 = [01000000], m1,3 = [00000001]
= [00001000], m2,2 = [00100000], m2,3 = [00000001]
m3,1 = [00000001], m3,2 = [00000001], m3,3 = [00100000]
With the direct method, we take M₁ = BBA1 and M2 = BBA2, and therefore the distance between Pref₁ 슥 C > A and Pref2º A > B is dF(M1, M2) = 2.8284. Because the maximal Frobenius distance is dF(M1, M2) ≈ 3.4641, the normalized distance between Pref₁ and Pref2 is dF(M1, M2) = 2.8284/3.4641 = 0.8165. This distance is bigger than the average-based distance Aver (Pref1, Pref2) = 0.6966, and the mid-based distance @mid(Pref1, Pref2) = 0.5 obtained by the brute force method (see subsection V-B). This result reinforces the conclusion that Pref₁ ≡ C > A is more dissimilar to Pref2 ≡ A > B than similar to Pref2 because dF(M1, M2) is much greater than 0.5. The advantage of this direct belief-based approach is that its conclusion is coherent with the conclusion drawn from the average attitude obtained by the brute force approach without the need for high combinatorics. This direct method has a quadratic complexity of 64N2.
With the indirect method using Jousselme distance [17] we get
$M_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0.8165 & 1 \\ 0.8165 & 1 & 0.8165 \\ 0 & 0.8165 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad M_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 0.8165 \\ 0 & 1 & 0.8165 \\ 0.8165 & 0.8165 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$       
Therefore, the Frobenius distance defined by (2) is d³ (Pref1, Pref2) ≈ 1.1835. Because dmax ≈ 2.4495, we get finally the normalized distance between Pref₁ and Pref2
$\bar{d}^J(\text{Pref}_1, \text{Pref}_2) \approx 1.1835 / 2.4495 = 0.4832.$
This distance value of 0.4832 is a little bit lower than @mid(Pref1, Pref2) = 0.5 obtained by the direct method above, and the brute force method based on mid attitude and on average attitude described in the subsection V-B. Hence, the conclusion drawn is now different from the conclusion drawn from the previous direct method because we will conclude that Pref₁ is a bit similar to Pref2 because d (Pref1, Pref2) is a bit lower than 0.5.
With the indirect method using belief-interval based distance [19] we get
$M_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0.7071 & 1 \\ 0.7071 & 1 & 0.7071 \\ 0 & 0.7071 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad M_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 0.7071 \\ 0 & 1 & 0.7071 \\ 0.7071 & 0.7071 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$       
Therefore, the Frobenius distance defined by (2) is
$\bar{d}^{BI}(\text{Pref}_1, \text{Pref}_2) \approx 1.0824$

sections.title: VII. CONCLUSION AND PERSPECTIVES
sections.content: In this paper, we have shown how it is possible to measure the distance between two PPOs either by a brute force method or by methods using belief functions that can properly model the uncertainty inherent in
